questions.text: A 55-year-old male presents with a verrucous carcinoma involving the glans penis. On examination, inguinal lymph nodes are not palpable. What is the most appropriate management for this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Partial penectomy is the treatment of choice for localized penile cancer limited to the glans.

  • In cases of localized verrucous carcinoma confined to the glans without lymph node involvement, partial penectomy is the standard approach.
  • It provides adequate oncological control while preserving penile function.
  • A surgical margin of 2 cm is typically recommended for distal lesions.
  • Total penectomy is reserved for more proximal or extensive tumors, while topical therapies like 5-fluorouracil are used for carcinoma in situ or superficial lesions.

choices.text: Intraosseous route access for giving IV fluids

questions.text: Identify the procedure being performed in the image given below.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The image shows intraosseous cannulation used for rapid vascular access to administer fluids or medications, especially in emergency settings.

  • Intraosseous (IO) access is used when peripheral IV access is difficult or delayed, such as in trauma, shock, cardiac arrest, or pediatric emergencies.
  • The technique involves inserting a needle into the medullary cavity of a long bone (usually proximal tibia, distal femur, or humeral head), which provides access to the rich venous plexus within the bone marrow that drains into the central circulation.
  • This allows for rapid administration of fluids, drugs, and even blood products.
  • Devices like the EZ-IO® use a battery-powered driver to insert the cannula quickly and reliably.

Explanation of other options:

Intraosseous cannula for pain relief (Option A): IO access is used for fluid and drug administration, not primarily for localized pain relief.

Bone marrow aspiration (Option B): Bone marrow aspiration typically involves the iliac crest and uses a specific aspiration needle, not a powered IO device. The technique and indication differ.

Bone marrow biopsy (Option D): A biopsy involves removing a solid core of marrow tissue, often done alongside aspiration. It requires a trephine biopsy needle, not the device shown in IO access.

choices.text: Anti-gas gangrene serum is indicated for all cases
Urinary diversion is the next step
A bilateral orchidectomy must be done

questions.text: A diabetic patient presents with sudden-onset severe perineal pain. On examination, there is foul-smelling discharge and visible necrotic tissue, as shown in the image. Which of the following is true regarding the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Fournier's gangrene is caused by a polymicrobial infection involving both aerobic and anaerobic organisms.

  • The clinical features and image are suggestive of Fournier's gangrene, a rapidly progressing necrotizing fasciitis of the perineum and genitalia.
  • It is most often seen in immunocompromised patients such as diabetics.
  • The infection is polymicrobial, commonly involving:
    • Aerobic bacteria: E. coli, Proteus, Klebsiella, Staphylococcus, Streptococcus
    • Anaerobic bacteria: Bacteroides, Clostridium, Peptostreptococcus
  • Fournier's Gangrene Overview:
    • Definition: Necrotizing infection affecting the perineum, genitalia, or perianal area.
    • Symptoms: Sudden perineal pain, foul discharge, crepitus, dusky skin, and eventual gangrene.
    • Progression Phases: From pain and erythema → crepitus → necrosis and sepsis.
    • Risk Factors: Diabetes, alcoholism, malnutrition, PVD, immunosuppression.
    • Management includes:
      • Fluid resuscitation and broad-spectrum antibiotics
      • Urgent surgical debridement
      • Urinary and fecal diversion in selected cases
      • Wound care and later skin grafting

Explanation of other options:

Anti-gas gangrene serum is indicated for all cases (Option A): Incorrect. Antitoxin is used for Clostridial gas gangrene, not all cases of Fournier's gangrene.

Urinary diversion is the next step (Option B): Incorrect. While urinary diversion may be required to prevent contamination, it is not the immediate next step-surgical debridement takes priority.

A bilateral orchidectomy must be done (Option C): Incorrect. Orchidectomy is reserved only if the testes are involved, which is not routine in all cases.

choices.text: Parasympathetic - bladder dysfunction and retrograde ejaculation
Sympathetic - retrograde ejaculation and bladder dysfunction
Sympathetic - impotence and loss of cutaneous sensation in the perineal region

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common complication following ligation of the first vessel during abdominoperineal resection (APR) for rectal carcinoma?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

High ligation of the inferior mesenteric artery during APR may injure sympathetic nerves, causing bladder dysfunction and retrograde ejaculation.

  • In abdominoperineal resection (APR), the first vessel ligated is typically the inferior mesenteric artery (IMA).
  • High ligation of the IMA risks damage to the superior hypogastric plexus, which carries sympathetic fibers.
  • Injury to these nerves leads to loss of sympathetic control over bladder neck closure and ejaculation, resulting in retrograde ejaculation and bladder dysfunction.
  • APR (Miles procedure) is done when rectal tumors involve the sphincter complex.
  • It involves two phases:
    • Abdominal phase: Ligation of IMA, mobilization of descending colon, dissection of rectum to levator ani.
    • Perineal phase: Excision of anus, sphincters, and rectum en bloc with perineal closure. A permanent colostomy is formed.
  • APR has higher recurrence rates compared to low anterior resection due to frequent positive circumferential margins.
  • Complications include:
    • Sympathetic nerve injury (most commonly affecting ejaculation and bladder function)
    • Anastomotic leaks, bleeding, strictures, necrosis of colon
    • Sexual dysfunction and recurrence risks (up to 33%)

Explanation of other options:

Parasympathetic - bladder dysfunction and retrograde ejaculation (Option A): Parasympathetic injury causes erectile dysfunction, not retrograde ejaculation.

Sympathetic - bladder dysfunction and impotence (Option B): Sympathetic injury causes bladder dysfunction and retrograde ejaculation, not impotence.

Sympathetic - impotence and loss of cutaneous sensation in the perineal region (Option D): Impotence is more linked to parasympathetic injury; sensory loss implies pudendal nerve damage, not sympathetic.

questions.text: A 28-year-old male presents with the following lesion over the chest that developed after a traumatic injury one year ago. The lesion has progressively enlarged and now extends beyond the original wound boundary. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Keloids are excessive scar tissue formations that extend beyond the original wound margin and do not regress spontaneously.

  • Keloids result from abnormal wound healing, characterized by uncontrolled collagen deposition that causes the scar to extend beyond the original site of trauma or surgery.
  • These scars are raised, firm, and often itchy or painful.
  • They do not regress over time and are more common in individuals with darker skin types.
  • The patient's history of trauma, followed by progressive scar growth beyond the original injury boundary, strongly supports the diagnosis of a keloid.

Explanation of other options:

Hemangioma (Option A): Benign vascular tumors present from birth or early infancy; unrelated to trauma and do not present as firm scar-like lesions.

Hypertrophic scar (Option B): Raised scar confined within the boundaries of the original wound; unlike keloids, these often regress over time and are less aggressive.

Neurofibroma (Option D): Benign nerve sheath tumor associated with neurofibromatosis; not typically linked to trauma and does not resemble a scar.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with pain over the right thigh following bilateral laparoscopic inguinal hernia repair done two weeks ago. He describes the pain as burning and tingling in nature, localized to the lateral aspect of the thigh. On examination, there is no motor weakness. What is the most likely nerve involved?
questions.solution:
Explanation of answer:

Laparoscopic hernia repairs commonly risk injury to the lateral cutaneous nerve of the thigh, causing meralgia paresthetica.

  • The lateral cutaneous nerve of the thigh (LCNT) is a purely sensory nerve that arises from the lumbar plexus (L2-L3) and passes under the inguinal ligament near the anterior superior iliac spine (ASIS).
  • In laparoscopic hernia surgeries, particularly when mesh fixation or electrocautery is used near the triangle of pain, this nerve can be injured or entrapped, leading to meralgia paresthetica-a condition characterised by burning pain, tingling, and numbness along the lateral aspect of the thigh.
  • This region is specifically vulnerable because the LCNT lies lateral to the gonadal vessels and is one of the nerves contained in the triangle of pain, a key anatomical landmark in laparoscopic surgery.
  • Overzealous dissection or improper tack placement in this triangle can result in chronic postoperative neuralgia.
  • Key Surgical Anatomy:
    • Triangle of Pain (in laparoscopic view):
      • Medial boundary: Gonadal vessels
      • Lateral boundary: Fold of peritoneum
      • Superior boundary: Iliopubic tract
  • Contents (medial to lateral):
    • Femoral branch of genitofemoral nerve
    • Anterior cutaneous nerve of the thigh
    • Lateral cutaneous nerve of the thigh
  • Common nerves injured in hernia surgeries:
    • Open repair: Ilioinguinal > Iliohypogastric > Genital branch of genitofemoral nerve
    • Laparoscopic repair: Lateral cutaneous nerve of thigh > Genitofemoral nerve

Explanation of other options:

Ilioinguinal nerve (Option A): Injury here is more common in open hernia repairs, not laparoscopic ones. It causes sensory loss over the upper medial thigh, root of penis, and scrotum-not lateral thigh pain.

Iliohypogastric nerve (Option B): Also more likely injured in open surgery. Provides sensation to the suprapubic area; does not explain isolated lateral thigh symptoms.

Femoral nerve (Option C): A mixed motor-sensory nerve; its injury leads to quadriceps weakness and sensory loss over the anterior thigh and medial leg, not isolated lateral thigh paresthesia.

questions.text: A patient is brought to the emergency department after a road traffic accident. On examination, he opens his eyes only to painful stimuli, speaks inappropriate words, and withdraws his limbs in response to pain. What is the most likely Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The GCS score is calculated based on the patient's responses: Eye opening to pain (E2), inappropriate verbal response (V3), and withdrawal to pain (M4).

  • The Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) is used to assess the level of consciousness in trauma patients.
  • It has three components:
    • Eye opening (E): To pain = 2
    • Verbal response (V): Inappropriate words = 3
    • Motor response (M): Withdraws to pain = 4
    • Thus, the total GCS = E2 + V3 + M4 = 9
  • GCS Interpretation:
    • Minor injury: GCS 15 with no loss of consciousness
    • Mild head injury: GCS 14-15 with loss of consciousness
    • Moderate head injury: GCS 9-13
    • Severe head injury: GCS 3-8
  • GCS-P is calculated by subtracting the Pupil Reactivity Score (PRS) from GCS:
    • PRS: 0 = both pupils reactive, 1 = one pupil unreactive, 2 = both unreactive
    • GCS-P range: 1-15
    • A GCS-P ≤8 indicates severe brain injury.

Reference:

https://www.glasgowcomascale.org/what-is-gcs-p/

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK513298/

choices.text: Echinococcus species is involved in etiology

questions.text: A patient presents with fever, abdominal pain, and jaundice. Imaging reveals the following findings. Which of the following statements is true regarding this condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The presence of a wavy internal membrane within a liver cyst strongly suggests hydatid disease caused by Echinococcus species.

  • Hydatid disease (echinococcosis) is a parasitic infection caused by Echinococcus granulosus, commonly transmitted via contact with infected dogs.
  • Humans are intermediate hosts, infected through oral ingestion of eggs from dogs.
  • The liver is the most frequently affected organ.
  • Typical features include abdominal pain, fever, and jaundice due to pressure effects or cyst rupture.
  • Imaging often reveals a characteristic serpentine or detached germinal membrane within the cyst.
  • Diagnosis:
    • Confirmed by serology (ELISA, immunoelectrophoresis) and imaging (USG, CT, MRCP).
    • Fine-needle aspiration is generally avoided due to risk of cyst rupture and anaphylaxis.
  • Treatment:
    • Options include the PAIR technique (Puncture, Aspiration, Injection, Reaspiration) combined with albendazole or praziquantel.
    • Surgery (pericystectomy, marsupialization) is reserved for large or complicated cysts.
    • Scolicidal agents like hypertonic saline or ethanol are used intraoperatively.
    • Cyst aspiration, followed by scolicidal agent application and sealing biliary communications.
    • Laparoscopic marsupialization (deroofing) for cysts.

Explanation of other options:

Surgery is mandatory (Option A): Surgery is not always necessary; medical and percutaneous options exist, especially for uncomplicated cysts.

Fine-needle aspiration cytology is diagnostic (Option B): FNA is contraindicated due to the risk of cyst rupture and anaphylactic shock.

Angioembolization is the treatment of choice (Option C): Angioembolization is not a standard treatment in hydatid disease and is typically unrelated to its management.

questions.text: A 55-year-old chronic alcoholic presents with unintentional weight loss. Laboratory findings reveal serum alkaline phosphatase (ALP) of 240 IU/L, alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) of 600 ng/ml, and normal AST and ALT levels. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Markedly elevated AFP with raised ALP and normal transaminases in a chronic alcoholic suggests hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC).

  • HCC is a primary liver malignancy, especially common in patients with chronic liver disease such as alcoholism.
  • A markedly elevated alpha-fetoprotein (AFP >400-500 ng/ml) is highly suggestive of HCC.
  • The patient's normal AST/ALT with elevated ALP indicates a hepatobiliary malignancy rather than inflammatory liver disease.
  • Tumor markers in HCC:
    • AFP >20 ng/ml is seen in ~70% of cases.
    • PIVKA-II (Protein Induced by Vitamin K Absence or Antagonism-II) may also be elevated.
  • Diagnosis:
    • Screening: Ultrasound (USG) for high-risk individuals.
    • Definitive imaging: Triple-phase CT scan is preferred.
      • Arterial phase: HCC shows arterial hyperenhancement.
      • Portal venous phase: Washout begins.
      • Delayed phase: Lesion appears hypodense due to venous washout - a classic feature of HCC.
  • Risk factors for HCC:
    • Cirrhosis, chronic alcohol use, HBV/HCV infections, NAFLD, aflatoxin exposure, anabolic steroids, and several genetic/metabolic disorders (e.g., Wilson's disease, α1-antitrypsin deficiency, porphyria cutanea tarda).

Explanation of other options:

Hepatic adenoma (Option A): Typically occurs in young women using oral contraceptives and does not elevate AFP.

Cholangiocarcinoma (Option B): May raise ALP but not AFP; associated with bile duct origin.

Alcoholic hepatitis (Option D): Usually shows elevated AST > ALT, not normal transaminases or elevated AFP.

questions.text: A patient presents with features of chronic pancreatitis, including recurrent attacks, and is found to have a 10 mm dilated pancreatic duct with intraductal calculi. Which of the following is the surgery of choice?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Longitudinal pancreaticojejunostomy is the procedure of choice in chronic pancreatitis with a significantly dilated duct (>7 mm) and intraductal stones to relieve obstruction and pain.

  • In chronic pancreatitis with a dilated pancreatic duct (≥7 mm) and intraductal calculi, the preferred surgical approach is Longitudinal Pancreaticojejunostomy (LPJ), also known as the Puestow procedure.
  • This technique involves opening the pancreatic duct along its length and anastomosing it to a loop of jejunum, thereby decompressing the duct and facilitating drainage of secretions and stones.
  • Rationale for LPJ:
    • Indicated when the main pancreatic duct is ≥7 mm with obstruction or stones.
    • Relieves pain caused by ductal hypertension.
    • Preserves pancreatic parenchyma.
    • Especially effective in patients with large duct disease.
  • Management overview of Chronic Pancreatitis:
    • Medical Management:
      • Pain management: Analgesics, enzyme supplementation (reduce pancreatic stimulation).
      • Diet: Low-fat, high-protein, high-carbohydrate diet.
      • Micronutrients: Supplementation of fat-soluble vitamins (A, D, E, K), vitamin B12, selenium, methionine, vitamin C, and E.
      • Enzyme supplementation: Reduces steatorrhea and may relieve pain.
      • Diabetes management: Often required due to islet cell damage.
    • Endoscopic Interventions:
      • ERCP with stenting or sphincterotomy: For patients with strictures or papillary stenosis but not first-line for large duct calculi.
    • Surgical Interventions:
      • LPJ (Puestow Procedure): For dilated duct with intraductal stones - surgery of choice in this case.
      • Frey Procedure: Combines LPJ with coring of pancreatic head, suitable when disease affects the head.
      • Beger Procedure or Pancreaticoduodenectomy (Whipple): Used when there is a mass lesion in the head.
      • Distal Pancreatectomy: For isolated tail disease.
      • Total Pancreatectomy: Reserved for diffuse disease and intractable pain.
  • For a patient with recurrent attacks of chronic pancreatitis, 10 mm dilated pancreatic duct, and intraductal calculi, the best surgical treatment is Longitudinal Pancreaticojejunostomy, as it directly decompresses the dilated duct and relieves obstruction.

Explanation of other options:

Pancreaticoduodenectomy (Option A): Major resection indicated for malignancies or mass lesions in the pancreatic head, not the treatment of choice for large duct chronic pancreatitis without a head mass.

ERCP and sphincterotomy (Option C): Useful in strictures or papillary stenosis, but less effective for large duct disease with calculi; also not long-term curative.

Coring of the pancreas head (Option D): Frey's procedure, indicated when there is disease in the head of pancreas; not preferred when the main duct is diffusely dilated with stones and no dominant head disease.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman undergoes a diagnostic mammogram for a palpable breast lump. Imaging reveals a BIRADS-5 lesion. A core needle biopsy confirms invasive ductal carcinoma. Which of the following findings, if present, would be considered a good prognostic factor for this lesion?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Estrogen receptor (ER) positivity indicates hormone sensitivity and is associated with a more favorable prognosis and treatment response.

  • BIRADS-5 lesion on breast imaging is highly suspicious for malignancy, with a >95% likelihood of cancer.
  • Once a breast carcinoma is confirmed, the prognosis depends on several tumor biology markers and patient-related factors.
  • ER (Estrogen Receptor) positivity is a favorable prognostic marker.
  • Tumors that express ER (and/or PR) are typically less aggressive, have slower growth, and respond well to hormonal therapies like tamoxifen or aromatase inhibitors.
  • These patients tend to have better long-term survival outcomes.
  • In contrast, markers such as BRCA mutations, p53 overexpression, and high Ki-67 are usually associated with more aggressive disease and poorer outcomes.

Explanation of other options:

p53 positive (Option B): Mutations or overexpression of the tumor suppressor gene p53 are associated with genomic instability and aggressive tumor behavior, correlating with poor outcomes.

High Ki-67 (Option D): Ki-67 is a cell proliferation marker. A high index suggests rapid tumor growth, which typically indicates a worse prognosis, although in some aggressive cancers it may predict chemosensitivity.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male presents with sudden, severe chest pain radiating to the neck and interscapular region. On examination, his blood pressure is 110/90 mmHg in the right upper limb and 160/100 mmHg in the left upper limb. Chest X-ray reveals a widened mediastinum. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Acute aortic dissection presents with tearing chest pain radiating to the back and unequal limb blood pressures, with widened mediastinum on X-ray.

  • Acute aortic dissection results from a tear in the intimal layer of the aorta, allowing blood to enter the media and create a false lumen.
  • This can compromise perfusion to branch vessels, explaining the asymmetrical blood pressure in the upper limbs.
  • Clinically, it presents with sudden, severe, tearing chest pain that may radiate to the back, particularly the interscapular region.
  • Chest X-ray may reveal a widened mediastinum, and in some cases, a left-sided pleural effusion may be seen.
  • DeBakey Classification(Based on the pattern of dissection):
    • Type I : Both ascending and descending aorta are involved
    • Type II : Only the ascending aorta is involved
    • Type III : Only the descending aorta is involved
  • Stanford Classification(Based on whether the ascending aorta is involved in aortic dissection):
    • Type A: Involves ascending aorta (includes DeBakey I & II) - requires surgical management.
    • Type B: Involves descending aorta only (DeBakey III) - often managed medically unless complications arise.
  • Investigations:
    • CT angiography is the investigation of choice in stable patients.
    • Transesophageal echocardiography (TEE) is preferred in unstable patients.

TEE of an aortic dissection within the descending part

  • MRI may be used if CT is inconclusive.

Explanation of other options:

Acute coronary syndrome (Option A): Presents with central chest pain radiating to the arm/jaw, often with sweating. Does not cause blood pressure differences between limbs or mediastinal widening.

Acute pulmonary embolism (Option B): Causes sudden-onset dyspnea, chest pain, tachycardia. Widened mediastinum and BP discrepancy are not typical features.

Esophageal rupture (Option D): Usually follows forceful vomiting (e.g., Boerhaave's syndrome), presenting with chest pain and mediastinal emphysema, not typically with widened mediastinum or asymmetric BP.

questions.text: A patient arrives with pain in the right upper abdomen. One week ago, the patient experienced a bout of diarrhoea. An abdominal CT scan shows a solitary liver abscess measuring approximately 25 cubic centimetres. What should be the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
Explanation of answer:

A small, uncomplicated liver abscess (≤5 cm or ~25 cc) in a stable patient is initially managed with medical therapy using broad-spectrum antibiotics.

  • Liver abscesses are commonly of pyogenic or amoebic origin.
  • In this case, the history of preceding diarrhoea and solitary liver abscess suggests a likely amoebic or secondary pyogenic abscess.
  • For abscesses that are small (≤5 cm or ≤30 cc), medical management is the first line, especially if the patient is stable and there are no features of rupture, sepsis, or multiloculated abscess.
  • Medical therapy involves:
    • Empiric broad-spectrum antibiotics for pyogenic abscesses (e.g., 3rd gen cephalosporins + metronidazole).
    • Metronidazole is also the drug of choice for amoebic abscesses.
  • Clinical and radiological monitoring is done.
  • Intervention (like percutaneous drainage) is only considered if:
    • There is no improvement within 48-72 hours.
    • The abscess is large (>5 cm), multiloculated, or about to rupture.
    • The patient is clinically deteriorating.

Explanation of other options:

PAIR (Option A): Puncture-Aspiration-Injection-Reaspiration is primarily used for hydatid cysts of the liver, not for pyogenic or amoebic abscesses.

Surgery (Option B): Reserved for complicated abscesses, such as those with rupture, inaccessible for percutaneous drainage, or secondary to intra-abdominal pathology (e.g., appendicitis). Not first-line for a small, uncomplicated abscess.

Percutaneous drainage (Option D): Indicated in larger abscesses (>5 cm) or when no response to medical therapy. For a 25 cc abscess, drainage is not routinely required unless there is clinical deterioration.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presents with confusion and ataxia one week after experiencing trauma. He has a significant history of chronic alcohol use, with his last drink two weeks ago. A CT scan reveals the following findings. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

CT scan reveals a crescent-shaped collection of blood following the contours of the brain and crossing suture lines. A crescent-shaped hemorrhage on CT that crosses suture lines is characteristic of subdural hematoma, commonly due to bridging vein rupture.

  • Subdural hemorrhage (SDH) typically results from tearing of the bridging veins that traverse between the brain surface and the dural sinuses.
  • It is often seen in elderly or alcoholic patients following minor trauma due to cerebral atrophy, which stretches the veins.
  • CT scan shows a crescent-shaped hyperdense collection that conforms to the shape of the brain and crosses suture lines.
  • In this patient with a history of alcohol dependence and recent trauma, the delayed onset of symptoms like confusion and ataxia along with CT findings are highly suggestive of a subdural hematoma.
  • SDH can be acute, subacute, or chronic, and the management ranges from conservative treatment in stable cases to surgical intervention (burr hole drainage or craniotomy) in symptomatic or enlarging hematomas.

Explanation of other options:

Intra-parenchymal hemorrhage (Option C): Involves bleeding within the brain tissue, often due to hypertension, cerebral amyloid angiopathy, or trauma. CT shows focal areas of hemorrhage within the brain substance.

Subarachnoid hemorrhage (Option D): Characterized by sudden severe "thunderclap" headache and blood in subarachnoid cisterns and sulci on CT, not as a crescent-shaped hematoma.

choices.text: Repeated radical surgery every 24 hours may be required to adequately manage this condition
This is a case of Meleney's gangrene
The condition is caused by β-hemolytic streptococcus and may sometimes be polymicrobial
Hyperbaric oxygen has no role in the treatment of this condition

questions.text: Which of the following statements is not true regarding the provided medical condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Hyperbaric oxygen therapy is beneficial in managing necrotizing infections like Meleney's gangrene and not contraindicated.

  • Meleney's gangrene is a form of necrotizing fasciitis, a rapidly progressive soft-tissue infection that involves synergistic polymicrobial activity, often with Group A β-hemolytic Streptococcus and anaerobes or facultative anaerobes such as Staphylococcus, E. coli, and Bacteroides. (Option B,C ruled out)
  • It typically affects post-surgical or immunocompromised patients, especially in the perineal or lower limb regions.
  • Common locations: Lower extremities in over 60% of cases.
  • Predisposing conditions include:
    • Diabetes mellitus
    • Smoking
    • Penetrating trauma (e.g., bites, abrasions)
    • Pressure sores
    • Immunosuppression
    • Intravenous drug abuse
    • Perineal infections (e.g., perianal abscess, Bartholin's cyst)
    • Skin infections (e.g., boils)
  • Clinical features:
    • Early signs:
      • Oedema extending beyond visible erythema
      • "Woody" or hard texture in subcutaneous tissues
      • Difficulty distinguishing fascial planes and muscles on palpation
      • Disproportionate pain compared to the affected area
      • Skin vesicles and soft-tissue crepitus
    • Absence of lymphangitis is typical.
    • Progression: Rapid onset of fever, tachycardia, and rapid progression to septic shock.
    • Radiological findings: Air in the tissues may be visible on radiographs, although urgent treatment should not be delayed for imaging.
  • Management requires:
    • Urgent surgical debridement of necrotic tissue—often repeated every 24 hours until only healthy tissue remains. (Option A ruled out)
    • Broad-spectrum IV antibiotics.
    • Supportive care, including fluid resuscitation and hemodynamic monitoring.
    • Hyperbaric oxygen therapy (HBO) is a useful adjunct as it enhances oxygen delivery to hypoxic tissues, inhibits anaerobic bacterial proliferation, boosts neutrophil activity, and aids in wound healing. Therefore, saying it "has no role" is incorrect.

questions.text: A patient presents with swelling in the groin region and is diagnosed with a direct inguinal hernia. Weakness in which of the following structures is most likely responsible for this condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Weakness of the conjoint tendon weakens the medial posterior wall of the inguinal canal, predisposing to a direct inguinal hernia.

  • The conjoint tendon is formed by the fusion of the internal oblique and transversus abdominis muscles and reinforces the medial portion of the posterior wall of the inguinal canal.
  • A direct inguinal hernia protrudes through Hesselbach's triangle, an area bounded by the inferior epigastric vessels, lateral border of rectus abdominis, and inguinal ligament.
  • Weakness of the conjoint tendon allows abdominal contents to herniate directly through the abdominal wall in this triangle, resulting in a direct inguinal hernia.

Explanation of other options:

Pectineal ligament (Option A): This forms part of the floor of the inguinal canal but is not directly involved in the pathogenesis of direct inguinal hernias.

Reflected part of inguinal ligament (Option C): While it contributes to the anterior wall of the canal, it is not primarily responsible for hernia formation.

Lacunar ligament (Option D): Though it supports the canal medially, it is not involved in the weakness that causes direct inguinal hernias.

choices.text: Candidal infection of the fingers due to continuous exposure to water
Continuous exposure to cement and concrete
Continuous exposure to drills and machines

questions.text: A construction worker presents to the OPD with complaints of white fingers. He has been working in the cement and concrete industry and has spent 20 years using heavy machinery drills and polishing wood and furniture. What is the most likely etiology for this condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Prolonged use of vibrating tools leads to Hand-Arm Vibration Syndrome (HAVS), a known occupational cause of secondary Raynaud's phenomenon or "vibration white finger."

  • The patient's description of "white fingers" in the setting of long-term use of vibrating tools-such as drills and wood polishers-is classic for Hand-Arm Vibration Syndrome (HAVS), also known as Vibration-Induced White Finger (VWF).
  • This is a form of secondary Raynaud's phenomenon triggered by repetitive exposure to vibration from handheld tools, commonly seen in construction workers, carpenters, and machinists.
  • Pathophysiology:
    • Repeated vibration causes damage to the digital blood vessels and nerves, resulting in vasospasm and reduced perfusion.
    • During cold exposure or even stress, the affected fingers may turn pale or white due to ischemia, then bluish (cyanosis), and finally red (reperfusion), mimicking classic Raynaud's phases.
  • Raynaud's Syndrome (Secondary):
    • Occurs due to an underlying cause (like collagen vascular disease or occupational hazard)
    • More severe than Raynaud's disease
    • May lead to digital ulcers or gangrene in chronic cases
    • Poor response to sympathectomy
    • Prevention is key: complete avoidance of vibrating tools
  • Treatment options include:
    • Calcium channel blockers (e.g., nifedipine)
    • Vasodilators
    • Steroids (in autoimmune causes)
    • Behavioral modifications

Explanation of other options:

Candidal infection of the fingers due to continuous exposure to water (Option A): Candida infections may affect wet hands but typically cause erythema and fissures, not vasospastic blanching of fingers.

Exposure to thinners and paints (Option B): Thinners can cause skin irritation or dermatitis, but they are not associated with vascular spasms or Raynaud-like symptoms.

Continuous exposure to cement and concrete (Option C): Cement exposure may lead to contact dermatitis or chemical burns, not episodic digital ischemia and color changes seen in vibration white finger.

questions.text: A 4-year-old child presents with a rectal polyp and painless rectal bleeding. Histopathological examination reveals enlarged and inflamed glands filled with mucin. The child is diagnosed with a juvenile rectal polyp. Which of the following best describes the polyp in this case?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Juvenile rectal polyps are hamartomatous growths most commonly seen in children under 5 years of age.

  • Juvenile rectal polyps are benign, hamartomatous growths, typically presenting in young children under the age of 5.
  • The hallmark clinical feature is painless rectal bleeding, often discovered incidentally or during evaluation for per rectal bleeding.
  • Histologically, these polyps exhibit dilated, mucus-filled glands lined by inflamed epithelium and surrounded by a lamina propria rich in inflammatory cells.
  • Though usually solitary, multiple polyps may be seen in juvenile polyposis syndrome, a condition that can be associated with mutations in genes like SMAD2, SMAD4, and BMPR1A.
  • These syndromic cases may also show extra-intestinal features such as digital clubbing and vascular malformations.
  • While juvenile polyps are benign, syndromic forms can carry a slightly increased risk of malignancy over time, especially if multiple or dysplastic polyps are present.

Explanation of other options:

Adenoma (Option A): Adenomas are benign neoplastic polyps that arise from glandular epithelium and are considered pre-malignant. While common in adults, they are rare in children and not the histological pattern seen in juvenile polyps.

Choristoma (Option B): Choristomas are ectopic normal tissue in abnormal locations, like pancreatic tissue in the stomach. They are not associated with juvenile polyps, which are overgrowths of normal colonic tissue.

Carcinoma (Option D): Carcinomas are malignant tumors derived from epithelial cells. They are exceptionally rare in children, especially under age 5, and do not match the benign histological findings of a juvenile polyp.

questions.text: Identify the given condition:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Trophic ulcers are neuropathic ulcers caused by sensory loss, often seen in diabetics, and are typically painless with punched-out edges in pressure areas.

  • Trophic ulcers, also known as neuropathic ulcers, occur due to loss of protective sensation, especially in the feet of patients with peripheral neuropathy-commonly from diabetes mellitus.
  • Because the patient does not feel pain, repeated trauma and pressure over bony prominences (e.g., metatarsal heads, heel) go unnoticed, leading to ulcer formation.
  • These ulcers typically:
    • Are painless
    • Have a punched-out appearance
    • Occur over weight-bearing areas
    • Are surrounded by callused skin
    • Show delayed healing due to impaired tissue perfusion and repeated trauma
  • In this case, the combination of diabetes, painless ulcer, pressure location, callus, and sensory loss is classic for a trophic (neuropathic) ulcer.

Reference:

https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC3036466/

questions.text: A 45-year-old man with long-standing varicose veins presents with brownish discoloration and eczema over his lower leg. According to the CEAP classification, which clinical stage does this finding correspond to?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The C4a stage of CEAP classification includes skin changes such as eczema and pigmentation associated with chronic venous insufficiency.

  • The CEAP classification system (Clinical, Etiological, Anatomical, and Pathophysiological) is used for grading chronic venous disorders.
  • Under the Clinical classification, C4a includes pigmentation and venous eczema, which result from chronic venous hypertension leading to hemosiderin deposition and inflammation.
  • These changes indicate progression from uncomplicated varicose veins or edema toward more severe skin complications.
  • Here is a breakdown of the Clinical component of CEAP:
    • CEAP Class Description
    • C0 No visible signs of venous disease
    • C1 Telangiectasia or reticular veins
    • C2 Varicose veins (>3 mm)
    • C3 Edema without skin changes
    • C4a Pigmentation or eczema
    • C4b Lipodermatosclerosis or atrophie blanche
    • C4c Corona phlebectatica
    • C5 Healed venous ulcer
    • C6 Active venous ulcer
  • CEAP also categorizes Etiology (Ec, Ep, Es, En), Anatomy (As, Ap, Ad, An), and Pathophysiology (Pr, Po, Pr,o, Pn) components.

Pigmentation/Eczema

LDS

Atrophic blanche

Corona phlebectatica

Reference:

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK557410/

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with a sudden, severe headache described as "the worst headache of her life." Her blood pressure is 160/100 mmHg. A non-contrast CT scan of the brain reveals a subarachnoid hemorrhage. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Angiography is the definitive next step to identify the source of bleeding, typically a ruptured aneurysm, in subarachnoid hemorrhage.

  • In the setting of a confirmed subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH) on CT scan, cerebral angiography-most commonly digital subtraction angiography (DSA)-is the next crucial step.
  • This allows identification of the bleeding source, typically a ruptured cerebral aneurysm, and helps plan for definitive treatment via surgical clipping or endovascular coiling.
  • While supportive care is also important, such as blood pressure control and preventing complications like vasospasm, localizing the aneurysm is a priority before proceeding to any definitive intervention.
  • Once the aneurysm is identified, treatment decisions are made depending on the location, size, and accessibility of the aneurysm, along with the patient's neurologic status.

Subarachnoid Hemorrhage:

  • Causes:
    • Most common: Trauma
    • Ruptured Aneurysm: Most commonly located in the Circle of Willis.
    • Arteriovenous Malformation (AVM)
    • Perimesencephalic SAH: Bleeding is confined to the basal cisterns due to venous bleeding and is associated with a better prognosis.
  • Risk factors:
    • Female sex
    • Hypertension
    • Smoking & Cocaine use
    • Genetic disorders (e.g., adult polycystic kidney disease, Marfan syndrome)
  • Symptoms:
    • Thunderclap Headache: Sudden and severe headache.
    • Associated with Seizures (10%), Unresponsiveness (50%) and Vomiting (70%)
  • Diagnosis:
    • CT Scan: First-line imaging, effective within 12 hours of onset, and its sensitivity decreases after one week.
    • Lumbar Puncture: Used if CT is negative but SAH is suspected.
    • Digital Subtraction Angiography (DSA): Gold standard for visualising aneurysms.
  • Management:
    • Surgical or endovascular intervention and addressing complications such as vasospasm and electrolyte imbalances.
    • Early and effective treatment is crucial for improving outcomes.

Explanation of other options:

Nimodipine (Option A): A calcium channel blocker used to prevent delayed cerebral ischemia due to vasospasm after SAH, but not the initial or most urgent step after diagnosis.

Surgery (Option C): Although surgical intervention is often necessary, angiography must precede it to precisely locate the aneurysm and decide whether surgery or endovascular coiling is appropriate.

Fibrinolytic therapy (Option D): Contraindicated in SAH; it increases the risk of worsening intracranial bleeding and is used for ischemic strokes, not hemorrhagic ones.

questions.text: A 20-year-old female presents with complete dysphagia after ingestion of a cleaning agent containing 90% sodium hydroxide. What is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Feeding jejunostomy provides nutritional support by bypassing the severely damaged esophagus during the acute phase of caustic injury.

  • Ingestion of strong alkalis like sodium hydroxide leads to caustic esophageal injury due to liquefative necrosis, saponification, and vascular thrombosis, resulting in extensive fibrosis and stricture formation.
  • In cases with complete dysphagia or full-thickness necrosis, early surgical nutritional support is crucial.
  • A feeding jejunostomy is the most appropriate initial step to ensure enteral nutrition while bypassing the esophagus, giving it time to heal and avoiding further complications such as perforation.
  • Corrosive esophageal injuries are graded:
    • 1st-degree burns: Only mucosal damage; oral feeds resumed after 48 hrs if painless swallowing returns.
    • 2nd/3rd-degree burns: Require fluid resuscitation, IV antibiotics, PPIs, steroids, and nutritional support via jejunostomy.
  • In severe cases with full-thickness necrosis, resection and cervical esophagostomy with jejunostomy may be necessary.
  • Long-term complications include stricture formation, managed by endoscopic dilatation (Savary-Gilliard, Eder-Puestow, or balloon dilators).
  • Surgical bypass or colonic transposition may be needed later if multiple strictures develop or the stomach is also involved.

Explanation of other options:

Esophagojejunostomy (Option A): Reserved for definitive reconstructive procedures after stabilization; not appropriate as the initial step in acute caustic injury.

Stent placement (Option B): Considered in strictures after healing; contraindicated in acute severe burns due to risk of perforation.

Gastrojejunostomy (Option D): Not indicated in esophageal injury; used when the stomach or pylorus is obstructed, commonly in corrosive acid injury affecting the antrum.

questions.text: A 23-year-old male patient presents with a swelling in the midline of his neck that shifts when he swallows or sticks out his tongue. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

A thyroglossal cyst presents as a midline neck swelling that moves with swallowing and tongue protrusion due to its embryological attachment.

  • A thyroglossal cyst arises from the persistence of the thyroglossal duct, an embryological remnant that connects the foramen cecum to the thyroid gland.
  • It typically presents as a midline neck mass that characteristically moves with deglutition and tongue protrusion-due to its anatomical relation with the hyoid bone.
  • The most common site is just below the hyoid (subhyoid region), though it may occur anywhere along the duct's course.
  • The definitive treatment is the Sistrunk procedure, which includes removal of the cyst, the tract, and the central portion of the hyoid bone to prevent recurrence.
  • Incision and drainage are contraindicated, as they may lead to thyroglossal fistula formation, which is always acquired and never congenital.

Explanation of other options:

Brachial cyst (Option A): Typically located laterally along the anterior border of the sternocleidomastoid muscle, not in the midline.

Plunging ranula (Option C): A mucous retention cyst from the sublingual gland, located in the floor of the mouth and lateral in position; does not move with swallowing or tongue movement.

Dermoid cyst (Option D): A congenital midline lesion, but it generally does not move with swallowing or tongue protrusion, distinguishing it from a thyroglossal cyst.

questions.text: A young patient presents with a 5-day history of fever along with hypotension, tachycardia, tachypnea, and altered mental status. Laboratory investigations reveal elevated WBC count, increased neutrophil percentage, and raised serum creatinine. The intern decides to use the quick Sequential Organ Failure Assessment (qSOFA) score to assess prognosis and predict hospitalization duration. Which of the following are components of the qSOFA score?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

qSOFA score includes systolic blood pressure ≤100 mmHg, respiratory rate ≥22/min, and altered mental status (GCS).

  • The qSOFA score is a bedside clinical tool used to identify patients with suspected infection at risk for poor outcomes like sepsis.
  • It includes three parameters:
    • Systolic Blood Pressure (SBP) ≤100 mmHg
    • Respiratory Rate (RR) ≥22/min
    • Altered mental status, assessed via Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS)
  • Meeting ≥2 of these 3 criteria indicates a higher risk of sepsis and the need for urgent evaluation and management.
  • Unlike full SOFA scoring, qSOFA does not require lab investigations, making it practical for initial bedside assessment.

Explanation of other options:

BP, RR, and CBC (Option A): CBC is not part of qSOFA; only SBP, RR, and GCS are used.

Creatinine, PR, and BP (Option B): Creatinine and pulse rate (PR) are part of full SOFA, not qSOFA.

RR, Body temperature, and PR (Option C): Body temperature and pulse rate are not qSOFA criteria.

choices.text: Chemotherapy is given along with radiation
Chemotherapy is given before radical surgery to reduce the bulk of the tumour
Chemotherapy is given after radical surgery for micrometastases

questions.text: A 54-year-old woman is diagnosed with stage 2A cervical cancer. The oncology team plans to administer chemotherapy before proceeding with radical surgery to reduce the tumour size. What is the meaning of neoadjuvant chemotherapy in this context?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Neoadjuvant chemotherapy is given before surgery to shrink the tumour and improve surgical outcomes.

  • Neoadjuvant chemotherapy (NACT) is administered prior to surgical intervention to reduce the tumour burden, increase the likelihood of successful tumour removal, and assess the tumour's response to systemic treatment.
  • This approach is part of Neoadjuvant Systemic Therapy (NAST), which may also include hormonal or targeted therapy.
  • Indications of Neoadjuvant Chemotherapy include:
    • Locally advanced cancers (e.g., T3, T4, N2, N3 breast cancer)
    • Early breast cancer when downsizing is needed for breast conservation
    • HER2/neu-positive and triple-negative breast cancers
    • Premenopausal women (<50 years)
    • Axillary node-positive disease
  • Neoadjuvant targeted therapy:
    • For HER2-positive tumours >5 mm, agents like trastuzumab and pertuzumab are used.
  • Neoadjuvant hormonal therapy:
    • Given to elderly or frail patients with ER/PR-positive tumours unfit for chemotherapy, though clinical response takes 3-6 months.

Explanation of other options:

Chemotherapy is given along with radiation (Option A): This describes concurrent chemoradiation, not neoadjuvant therapy.

Chemotherapy is given during surgery (Option B): This is incorrect; chemotherapy is not typically administered intraoperatively.

Chemotherapy is given after radical surgery for micrometastases (Option D): This describes adjuvant chemotherapy, not neoadjuvant.

questions.text: A patient presents with sudden onset of hematemesis. She has a history of arthritis for which she takes aspirin, consumes alcohol occasionally, and also reports sporadic abdominal pain. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Peptic ulcer is the most likely diagnosis due to the presence of risk factors like aspirin use, alcohol intake, and abdominal pain.

  • Peptic ulcers, occurring in the stomach or duodenum, are a common cause of upper gastrointestinal (GI) bleeding and typically present with hematemesis.
  • In this case, the patient's history of aspirin use (a known ulcerogenic NSAID), occasional alcohol consumption (which irritates the gastric mucosa), and episodic abdominal pain all support the diagnosis of a peptic ulcer.
  • These factors compromise the gastric mucosal barrier and increase the risk of ulcer formation and bleeding.
  • Most common artery involved in bleeding ulcers:
    • Duodenal ulcer - Gastroduodenal artery
    • Gastric ulcer - Left gastric artery

Reference:

Upper Gastrointestinal Bleeding - StatPearls - NCBI Bookshelf

Oesophagitis

questions.text: What is the most probable diagnosis for a 40-year-old male patient who has swelling that has been gradually increasing in size over the last two years, with variable consistency and complete mobility upon examination?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

A parotid tumor typically presents as a slow-growing, painless, mobile swelling with variable consistency, matching the clinical description.

  • The clinical scenario of a 40-year-old male with a gradually increasing swelling over two years, variable consistency, and complete mobility is characteristic of a parotid tumor, the most common salivary gland tumor.
  • These tumors often present in the preauricular region and may go unnoticed for years due to their painless nature and slow growth.
  • They are typically benign, with pleomorphic adenoma being the most common type.
  • The parotid gland is highly mobile in the preauricular region, explaining the free mobility of the tumor.
  • The variable consistency may suggest mixed cellular components seen in pleomorphic adenomas, which often have both epithelial and stromal elements.

Explanation of other options:

Dermoid cyst (Option A): Dermoid cysts are usually congenital, present at birth, and grow very slowly. They typically have a uniform consistency, unlike the variable consistency seen in this case.

  • Common sites: External angular dermoid is the most common type.
  • Symptoms: Painless, soft, smooth, and non-tender swelling.
  • Diagnosis: CT scan to rule out intracranial extension.
  • Treatment: Surgical excision.

Sebaceous cyst (Option C): These are epidermoid cysts, not true sebaceous origin lesions. They usually present as a superficial skin swelling with uniform consistency and may have a central punctum (except on scalp/scrotum).

  • Content: White, cheesy, keratinous material (not sebum).
  • Characteristic: Typically non-mobile relative to deeper tissues and don't grow as slowly over years like parotid tumors.

Cervical lymph node (Option D): Cervical lymphadenopathy usually presents as firm, discrete swellings, which may be tender (especially in infections) and less mobile when compared to freely mobile tumors.

  • Etiology: Infection, malignancy, or autoimmune disease.
  • On palpation: Often firmer, less fluctuant, and more nodular than described in the stem.
